RMP Executive Summary


1.0 RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Roche Colorado Corporation currently uses Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Program (RMP) regulated chemicals below threshold quantities with the exception of Piperidine. Roche Colorado Corporation has evaluated the requirements of the RMP rule and has reviewed present emergency management practices.  Roche Colorado Corporation has determined that current practices meet or exceed the requirements of RMP.  This updated plan is being submitted because the process that uses titanium tetrachloride is discontinued.  Titanium Tetrachloride has not been stored on site for the past six months. 

Roche Colorado Corporation is a member of the American Chemistry Council's Responsible Care? program certified to the RC14001/ISO 14001 standard. Responsible Care? consists of a comprehensive management system designed to address risks associated with the handling of chemicals including site security.  Moreover, Roche Colorado Corporation has an extensive process safety management program designed to satisfy all of Occupational Safety & Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management program requirements and the RMP.  Roche Colorado Corporation is dedicated to working with the community emergency response authorities to address the potential for releases that could affect the public.  Roche Colorado Corporation employs physical and administrative controls to mitigate potential releases.  Roche Colorado Corporation implements extensive internal training to prevent releases as well as prepare for eventualities which may result from releases.  Roche Colorado Corporation is an active member of the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and endeavors to prepare the LEPC for the possibility of responding to releases that could originate from Roche Colorado Corporation. 

2.0 PROCESS DESCRIPTION AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

Roche Colorado Corporation has one regulated substances u

nder 40 CFR 68 that exceeds the plan threshold: piperidine.  

Piperidine:  Roche Colorado Corporation uses piperidine (CAS #110-89-4) in the production of pharmaceutical intermediates, and in performing research and development of new and/or improved pharmaceutical processes.  Specifically, piperidine is used in the production of anti-HIV/AIDs pharmaceuticals.  Pharmaceuticals are primarily produced via synthesis routes involving organic chemicals.  

Piperidine is an organic chemical used in the synthesis of pharmaceuticals.  The piperidine threshold for triggering applicability of 40 CFR 68 is 15,000 pounds per process.  The main process vessel containing piperidine has a worst case capacity greater than 15,000 pounds.

Piperidine is a chemical with a pungent odor that is readily detectable below concentrations of concern.  The odor is described in literature as amine-like, heavy, sweet, floral, animal odor, odor of pepper.  Due to the odor, exposed persons will not voluntarily stay in areas of even low concentrations.  Little data regarding exposure limits is available in the literature, however Roche Colorado Corporation has been advised by expert toxicologist's to consider the following concentrations for emergency response planning purposes:
    
    1 ppm: It is believed that nearly all individuals could be exposed up to this airborne concentration for up to one hour without experiencing other than mild, transient adverse health effects or without perceiving a clearly defined objectionable odor. 

    10-100 ppm: It is believed that nearly all individuals could be exposed up to this airborne concentration range for up to one hour without experiencing or developing irreversible or other serious health effects or symptoms that could impair an individual's ability to take protective action.

    100-1000 ppm: It is believed that nearly all individuals could be exposed up to this airborne concentration range for up to one hour without experiencing or developing life threate

ning health effects.

Anticipated health effects are acute irritation/toxicity including skin irritation, corrosive effect on human tissue, nausea.  

3.0 GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

Roche Colorado Corporation has been in compliance with OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) program for a number of years.  The EPA has said that a process in compliance with OSHA PSM is also in compliance with RMP program level 3.  The processes containing piperidine at Roche Colorado Corporation is RMP program level 3.  All elements of OSHA PSM has been implemented for the piperidine containing process.

Key aspects of the PSM program include: process safety information reviews, process hazard analysis, operating procedure documentation and review, class room and on-hands training prior to system operation, mechanical integrity program, management of change program, pre-startup reviews, incident investigation, routine compliance audits, hot work permit program, contractor qualification, and employee participation in process safety reviews.

4.0 FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no accidents involving RMP regulated chemicals in the last five years that have affected offsite receptors or have resulted in significant loss of property or injury of personnel.

5.0 EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Roche Colorado Corporation has a comprehensive emergency response plan that addresses employee, contractor and public safety.  Moreover, Roche Colorado Corporation is committed to the protection of both its employees and the public.

6.0 PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Roche Colorado Corporation has a proactive incident investigation program that acts as a continuous mechanism to evaluate and improve safety.  A Compliance Team consisting of environmental, safety and regulatory affairs representatives conduct weekly audits and follow up of all incident reports.  Incidents are tracked according to the program and a system is in plac

e to coordinate close out of action items and improvement of all environmental and safety control systems.  The Compliance Team conducts monthly training of employees to communicate issues and improvements learned via the audits and incident reports. 


Ver. 8/17/07
